element_texts.text: Completed

postcard  HOTEL INTER-CONTINENTAL   3,  rue de Castiglione, PARIS 1er    La Terrasse Fleurie   The Garden Court
postmark  CHICAGO ILL  14 NOV 1972
note next to postmark:  This was written in Paris - but we didn't have your address - Art
Darling Jack & Theodora - Today at lunch I met Art & Lila Weinberg.  Sooner or later I knew we would find common soil.  It is you!  I've been living in Paris going on 6 yrs - earning my living as painter, writer, translator what not.  My 19 yr old daughter in college in Calif.  15 yr. old here.  I have thought of you more often tahn you'd believe.  My address 4 rue du Delta Paris 75009  tel. 285-2229  Paul lives in Calif.  Love, love to both of you.  Mary Guggenheim
different handwriting   Meeting Mary here in Paris, learning of our mutual friends - the Moberly contingent was exciting.
Comes the revolution everybody will visit Paris - Best from Lila and Arthur
different ink, same as Conroy address  5421 Cornell - Chicago
Mr & Mrs Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri 65270
Completed

IMAGE cabin in snow   front and back of greeting card
of course we're still holding out in Hyde Park.  Come see us next time you're in Chicago.  It's time for a good visit - and we'd love it.  We'll get the Dec. underlined:  Amer. Libraries for your next chapter - We're doing a biog of Darrow ( to be publ by Putnam's).  Due April 1976 - so we're really pushing.
Lots of love - and please come -
Arthur & Lila
Completed

postcard COPPER PAVILION    Chinese stamp, illegible postmark
Jack Conroy  701 Fisk Ave   Moberly 65270 Mo.  USA
Nov 17
Dear Jack

   This is a trip to remember - Such masses of people all pretty much in charge of their destiny & certainly working for the better life & seeing results.  older people know full well what they  have gained.   We are given the message in art - song - & dance over & over.  They are a warm gracious, talented people & we are VIP's they take us everywhere & explain there Pre & Pro liberation life to us always,  There is no place in the world where the masses have been thus liberated & they are happy.  I h ope you get here - I've been reading your book but shall give it to the interpreters when we leave.  Now in Tiensin on our way to Nanking & then Shanghai Tokyo & home.  Its tiring but great  Best am
Completed

postcard  NANKING HOTEL  File:Drawing of hotel building
postmark  U.S. POSTAL SERVICE, CA  920  PM   22 DEC 1974
827 Loma Riviera Dr.  San Diego 29110 Ca.
Jack Conroy family
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly 65270 Mo.
Completed

back of envelope  259 North Chung Shan  Road Nanking China   Chinese characters and 259 above the English ones
Stayed here - lovely city.
Amelie Weinfield  (Woldenberg)
[[IMAGE: Charity stamps:  ARTHRITIS AN ALL AGE DISEASE Raggedy Ann doll in wheelchair   Christmas seal stamps;  GREETINGS 1974   1974 CHRISTMAS  snowman with two children; mailman with bag full of Christmas gifts   ]]
Completed

in pencil in top margin  [1974]
File:Painted flowers in right and lower margins
Dear Jack & family -

   This sure was the month that was.  Wish I could share it with you - You gotta go -
   I hope your book goes over & that you get some royalties to travel on.  
   I'm beat - went so fast - But I'll tell you - it takes 800,000,000 people all working & thinking alike to make a classless society.  This is the 1st I've seen & who knows if it will last.  It's something to see  how hard & proudly every man, woman & child works at it. ----------
   Have a good year - & many years

Best
am
Completed

letterhead   PHARES K. WEIS SR.   820 WEST REED   MOBERLY, MO.  65270
Sept 25, 1975
Dear Jack,

    PK Jr placed your card on my desk.  It is always good to hear from you.
    The title, "Sage of Moberly" is well placed.  Surely you have well earned it - and I have found you always tell it like it is.
    I promise never to question the authenticity of any tale you tell.  I know you will return the favor if and when there is an opportunity.
    Regards

Cordially
PK Weis
Completed

in pencil in top margin  ILDA WEISS
3428 E. Marsh St.
Stockton, Calif.
May 4, 1944
Dear Jack,

     Thanks for your kind letter and offer to help me.  I am getting a patent for my idea as a 'Method of Teaching' and in a few weeks I am supposed to get something that will state I have applied for the patent, so then I would be safe in showing it to some Company unclear smudge    I will send you a sample of my idea soon - I seem so busy working every day - it is really very simple - one language is printed over another one - but one only is visible at a time - as you choose you can change from one to the other - in reading a novel written this way one has a continual translation - without blurred text a dictionary or loose
Completed

the thread of a story.   If my idea proves satisfactory you might be able to take your novels "A World to Win" and "The Disenherited [sic]" which I believe are already translated into Russian and have them reprinted together it would have a large sale here to students studiing [sic] Russian and in Russia to students studing [sic] English.

    George wrote another friend Putnam he it seems is a professional translator so what little material I have on hand I am sending him as his opinion would be valuable - I know very little about a foreign language myself.
    Here's hoping it will work out good for all of us - I cannot tell you how much I have enjoyed all of your books - that goes for all my family -  If I could spell better I could write a great deal of my opinion on all Proletarian Lit And I think you were the first to set the style - and now its gone even to China - I have just finished "Village in August"  My blurred writing
Completed

P.S.  I told Dr. Eiseley you would guffaw when you read in the [[underlined: ?] Index]] that I was billed as "writer-author"!
June 18, 1971
Dear Mr. Conroy -

     Just to tell you I am sorry I didn't get to see you again while I was in Moberly.  Unexpectedly I got involved  with my sister's moving and did not get to do many of the things I had planned while in Moberly.
     I was back for the class reunion, of course, and you would probably be amused at the enthusiasm of all these men and women meeting each other after forty years.   Somehow, we were all magically young, those forty years had never even underlined:  happened.
     I did a lot of cemetery wandering in Moberly & Huntsville & even  up in an old family cemetery "somewhere around Jacksonville."   All I know is that to get there one crosses Mud Creek underlined:  twice.
Completed

-2-

    When I tell my friends here how wonderful Moberly is, they only look at each other wearily and don't believe a word I say.  Well, maybe it isn't just Moberly I think is so wonderful, maybe it is the field of daisies & wild roses I stood in somewhere between Mt. Airy & Armstrong.
     I hope you don't get so tied up doing reviews that you neglect your autobiography.  Dr.  Eiseley is having a book underlined:  The Night Country  out this fall.  It is an easier book for him than most.  Though, because it mostly consists of material that has been published in magazines through the years.
     Again, I'm so sorry I didn't have time for a longer visit with you.  I wanted to meet Ms. Conroy and your fine dog.

Sincerely,
Peggy E. Werkley
Completed

letterhead   UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA  PHILADELPHIA  19104
LOREN EISELEY  Benjamin Franklin Professor  Anthropology and the History of Science
DEPARTMENT OF ANTHROPOLOGY  UNIVERSITY MUSEUM  33rd and Spruce Streets
Nov.  29, 1973
Dear Mr. Conroy -

        I thought you might enjoy seeing the article on p. 31 - in case  you don't already have a copy from someone.

Sincerely, 
Peggy Elsen Werbley
Completed

-3-
when I am in book stores, so I did the same for yours.  Hopefully you both will sell out there and the books will be rendered.

   All good luck with your autobiography.  Remember to keep me in mind as your librarian & secretary when I come back to Moberly to live!

Sincerely, 
Peggy Werkley
July 24, 1974
Dear Mr. & Mrs. Conroy:

     This is just to tell you how nice it was to visit with you while I was in Moberly.  Incidentally, I saw Marjorie Hunter and she told me your house was built from wood that was used at the
Completed

-2-
Worlds Fair in St. Louis in 1904, although I am sure you know all that.  Her grandfather, Mr. Lowell, was one of the "witnesses" at my parents' wedding.

    Out book shopping this afternoon I noticed your underlined:  Disinherited  in the paperback store right next to Dr. Eiseley's underlined:  Darwin's Century.  I always stand Dr. Eiseley's books up so they will be easily noticed
Completed

greeting card
File:Metal angel blowing trumpet
next summer when I make my annual pilgrimage to Moberly.  My sister & I would like to buy a house together, but alas we have always been spendthrifts & will not be able to.  We  have been grasshoppers instead of ants - or am I getting that right?

  Anyway, I love your house, & that is the kind of house I would want. -
   All good vibes for the new year -

Affectionately
Peggy Wabley
Completed

greeting card  CHRISTMAS GREETINGS AND GOOD WISHES FOR THE NEW YEAR
Affectionately, Peggy E. Werbley
Dear Mr. & Mrs. Conroy

  I do hope your autobiography is coming along fine.  I still wish I could retire to Moberly & be your secretary.   I will never feel at home in Philadelphia.  Your nice friend Ashley Buck writes me from time to time.  I will look forward to seeing you again
Completed

greeting card TREE  RUBBING FROM A STONE TABLET, AFTER A CHINESE PAINTING BY LI WÊN-HAN, 1845
-3-
have a  long recuperation.  He had had another operation the day after Christmas so I am sure he is ready to say goodby to hospitals forever.  I did tell  you, too, underlined:  I think that he's having a volume of poetry out from Scribner's in October of this year & has kindly dedicated it to my mother, who would be mighty proud.

   The little hearts on the front of this card hanging from the tree were not put there by the original artist, Li Wên-Han, but by me, & are valentines for you and Mrs. Conroy from me.  Sincerely, Peggy Werbley
Completed

January 30, 1977
Dear Mr. Conroy -

   I've been wondering, since you said you had no copy of the Christmas piece you wrote for Mr. Kingsbury; if you would like to have the original I have here.  I treasure it, and have these years, but certainly think you ought to have one for your files.  Just let me know about it.  As I write this, I have a feeling that
Completed

-2-
perhaps I underlined: already  wrote to ask you this but maybe I just wrote you a similar letter in my head earlier.  Do you ever have this happen to you?  I write so many mental letters that I get terribly confused whether or not I have written the actual ones.

    Anyway, I underlined: know I didn't tell you that Dr. Eiseley had a very serious operation last week at the U. of Pa. hospital.  Fortunately all went well and he will be fine but will
Completed

P.S.  I am very proud that you inscribed the copy of your story that you gave me.  I'll be watching for "The Jack Conroy Reader"
Sept. 24, 1977
Dear Jack -

    I loved your story "The Morphadite" and the only reason I am so late in telling you so is that closing up my sister's house in St. Louis was really too big a chore for my other sister & me and I could scarcely move by the time I returned home this past Tuesday.  # - Now, when I was nine I had never heard of a morphadite except that at carnivals I do remember
Completed

-3-
there was usually the"half-man, half-woman," which I always accepted as I did other wonders of life.  Your story had great charm, was utterly delightful, and will be a fine addition to your autobiography.

    Your reminiscences of  your youth are so marvelous that I still think your autobiography might be one of youth alone - although then, of course,
Completed

greeting card  PORTRAIT OF A PRINCE  Persian, 16th Century, Safavid period by Muhammad Harawi  Freer Gallery of Art  Smithsonian Institution  Washington, D.C. (37.8)
and keep the autobiography flowing.  

   And if you hire me as your librarian when I come back to Moberly I'll fix up (catalogue) all your manuscripts as I am to do Dr. Eiseley's.  Affectionately Peggy Werkley

-3-
the reader would miss the fascinating accounts of your writing, editing, knowledge of well-known people, etc.   Couldn't you do ten autobiographies?

  I myself put a chair nightly underneath the inside knob of the door, as did your mother - not to keep out morphadites but other horrors that have invaded what  used to be a more secure world.
   It was great seeing you and Gladys - if I may be so familiar & call you by first names.  Do keep well
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Peggy Werkley
October 9, 1977
Dear Jack -

    I am delighted to hear about your wonderful honor, and certainly no one deserve it more than you do.  I am glad to know that the Missouri Library Association showed such good judgment.  This should spur you on with the autobiography.
    Incidentally I have an idea for a picture for your book jacket.  If you do leave the autobiography a boyhood account, or largely so, what about using a young boy photograph?  I think this would be different - maybe it has been done before, I don't know.  But Dr. E. had a darling photograph of himself at about age three sitting holding a book and I alway [sic] told him underlined:  that was the photograph I
Completed

My moving bill to Moberly, what with the Australopithecine statue I told you I had from the office, this head, & mountains of antique china, will be a fortune - but my 2nd worry (after paying moving bill) - is where I will find a large enough apartment for the money I can pay.  But that I will worry about when the time comes.

     I hope Ashley Buck and his wife did get to come see you and if so I'm sorry I did not get to meet them.
     It  was so good seeing you and Gladys when I was in Moberly.  Do both keep well, and you keep the autobiography flowing.  And think of that young boy photo.  I think it would be different and fitting if the book is largely about younger days.

Sincerely,
Peggy Werkley
Completed

-2-
saw in my mind for use on a journal - which of course now will never be.

   I wish you all good luck on your underlined:  Reader scheduled for publication this spring and am looking forward to it eagerly.
   Work progresses on Dr. E's anthology of his works which he planned and outlined before his death.
   I have so much to do in the assembly of his manuscripts and cataloging them and all the other things to be done for the University that I don't know how I shall ever finish.  I'm trying to keep all of his books that he signed in special section, association copies in one next to it, etc.  Let me give you a suggestion - sign your books, not just your own, but those in your
Completed

-3-
library, double underline:  now, if only a few a day.  I used to try to get Dr. E to do this but there was always so much to do, as I am sure is true in your case.  But a signed book does make so much difference in a collection.

   This morning, even though it is Sunday - because Sat. & Sun. are working days for me, too, since I like the work - I am going over to the study in Dr. E's home office (he had 3 offices altogether) to search out signed volumes.  Later on a young sculptress who did a head of him (you should have that done, too,) & incidentally this girl, though young, is good, I think) is bringing it over.  She did one in plaster (is that right?) that will go in the Provost's office and the same in bronze for a proposed Loren Eiseley Room at the U.   She also kindly made me a plaster one.
Completed

-4-
return - if your rent is not too high.   I have a lovely roomy apartment here  & have it filled with books, antiques, Paleolithic tools, a head of Dr. E, a statue of an underlined: Australopithicus africanus, etc., so I have underlined:  got to get a fairly roomy apt.

     I am underlined:  so glad that you are appreciated as you should be & my mother, in Paradise, would be saying, "I always knew Jack Conroy was a special person."  She told me so.
     I heard from Ashley Buck recently.  I had asked him for the address of a place where I could sell old journals, both for myself & Mrs. Eiseley.  I have old underlined:  Fiction Parades,

a underlined:  Story or two & she has a lot of underlined:  Prairie Schooners  & other magazines of that vintage.

  I am working myself to death here & I think I will stay in bed for a week when I come back to Moberly.  I have a lovely canopy bed that is like a little house.  Again, I am underlined:  so thrilled about your $7500 fellowship & love your photograph.  My best love to Gladys & to you - Peggy E. Werbly
Completed

The Wyndam Apts. - A-302
Wynnewood, Pa. 19096
Nov. 17, 1977
Dear Jack -

    I was so delighted to receive that wonderful picture of you - what a treasure to have -underlined:  and inscribed.   Thank you so much for thinking of me because you knew I would love it.  The photographer did a great job, incidentally, posing you against the "ghost" station.   I think I rode out on the last train to leave the station, but I cannot possibly tell  you the date.  Anyway the train was hours late arriving and later I was told it was The Last Ride.
    Of course I will be most happy to send Dianne Myer a copy of my book.  Fortunately I am able to because I only had one copy left and a friend told me the books were for sale in some book catalogue for $1.  Since the minimum order was $5 I had to order
Completed

-2- 
five & now am glad I did.  And not just because I want an award in the Next World, altho that would be nice, too.  I underlined:  believe I once met Dianne Myers but she would not remember me.

    I am overcome with joy for you that you received the National Endowment of the Arts fellowship for $7,500!  underlined:  Anybody can use that amount, or I can use $350, which I am getting for selling an article/story to underlined:  Country Journal, if you've ever heard of it.  Incidentally, a piece from your autobiography might fit there. It's country oriented, edited by my former editor at American Heritage, who always seemed to have faith in me & actually asked me to send him something for his journal.
Completed

-3-

  $350 is a fortune to me & I am rattling around in my cartons of stories trying to come up with something else.  The editor cut out one cemetery - the piece  had 3 - & a lot of ancestors - they won't care if their descendant needs the cash, as I do
    Dr. E. got a wonderful review from Edmund Fuller in underlined:  Wall St  Journal & a bad one in a Chicago paper.  I hope he doesn't care about reviews wherever he is in the universe.  underlined:  I care, though.  Only my sense of responsibility to take care of his papers - and the fact that I underlined:  have to go on here thru Feb. to get enough retirement, keeps me from heading for Moberly tomorrow.  I am eager to be "home" & look forward to having you & Gladys as dinner & talking companions.  Why don't you use some of your $7500 & fix up a nice apt. for me in your house & I'll grocery shop for you in
Completed

duplicate of previous page   992006198805867_midwest_ms_conroy_box_00033_fl_01660_000061.jpg
in pencil in top margin  Werkley, Peggy  [1977]
Dear Mr. Conroy:

      I wanted you to know that if you would like to have the original of the piece you wrote for Mr. Kingsbury you are welcome to it.  I treasure it and have all these years but I think you ought to have an original for your files.  So do let me know if  you'd like it.
     Did I tell you Dr. Eiseley had a serious operation right after Christmas, following a minor one previous to that?  In spite of it all he'll have a book of poetry out next fall (Scribners) & has 

-2- 
kindly dedicated it to my mother - maybe I've already told you that.  She would have been so proud.

  My best regards to Mrs. Conroy -

Sincerely,
Peggy E. Werkley
Completed

in pencil in lower right margin  Werkley, Peggy   Wynnewood, PA  Dec. 1977
greeting card  HOLIDAY GREETINGS and Best Wishes for a Happy New Year
Dear Gladys & Jack         Affectionately,  Peggy Werkley
I got the book off to your friend, as you requested, Jack.  Are  you having fun spending  double underlined: $7500?  I would.  I am having such fun with Dr. Eiseley's papers.  It would please him, I am sure.  I just came across a couple of letters he had written to U.S. presidents - expressing his views on foreign policy.  I shall probably look like a mole (not underlined:  male ) by the time I come to Moberly, being immersed for months in paper, paper, paper.  I do hope you are both well & have a fine Christmas.
Completed

Jan. 21, 1978
Dear Jack -

    As a member of the Manuscript Society I get a lot of catalogues.  I thought you would be interested in the enclosed "Tennessee Williams' Copy"  underlined:  Midland Humor,  ed. by Jack Conroy ...... A long inscription by Conroy to Williams recalling "the golden age of St. Louis:, in fly leaf....$75.00 --
   So you see you are worth a lot of money! -
   Since I didn't hear from you all at Christmas I have been worried that you might
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Werkley, Peggy
-2-
be ill.  I do hope you will let me know how you & Gladys are.

   I am working hard (even on week-ends & holidays) on the Loren Eisely collection for the U. of Pa.  I definitely plan, however, to leave here the end of July for Moberly.  My son Christopher will drive me back.  I am really looking forward to living in Moberly, altho' I am afraid I wont be able to get such delicacies as Major Gray's chutney there.
   I'm working on a terribly exciting project (to me) concerning famous paleoanthropologists of the 2nd quarter
Completed

back of greeting card Wild flowers  Watercolor   Henry Newman, American, about 1833-1918  Ross Collection, Gift of D. W. Ross  Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
PRINTED IN SWITZERLAND FOR H. GEORGE CASPARI, INC.
-3- 
of this century, from a file in Dr. Eiseley's papers.  I --underlined:  hope to  sell an article about it & am so excited about the man involved  ( F. O. Barlow, a famous member of anthropological casts in England) that I even drink a toast to him every underlined:  evening.  But then, I am a very sentimental person.

  I do hope you & Gladys are getting along well - & remember your autograph is worth money!

Sincerely,
Peggy Werkley
Completed

July 12, 1978
Dear Jack & Gladys -

    My sister sent me a wonderful news story about you, Jack, with a fine photograph, & I was so pleased that you are getting thus honored continually, as you certainly should be.
    I am in the midst of the worst confusion I have ever been in - getting ready to move the end of this month - my son is driving me to Mo. and trying to finish the Eisely project.  I have 3 or 4 Eiseley books to go & will probably have to bring some
Completed

greeting card  Wishing you all things rare and beautiful
-2-
cartons home with me & work on them.

  I would not repeat a job like this cataloguing one again ever.  It was exciting, fun & I loved it at first but I am working under too much pressure, as I have for years.  I plan to buy a house & dog when I get to Moberly - or rather Chris, because of his youth & being able to get a mortgage will "buy" the house & my sister & I will live in it.  I'm looking forward to this, altho' perhaps it's foolish to take on a house at this stage of life.  But no apt. would let me put up all my book shelves & bring in some of my anthropological objects.
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Werkley, Peggy  [1978]

   I have some nice skeletal casts that might not be everyone's cup of tea.
   I hope you both are well & that the autobiography is going well.  I have not heard from Ashley Buck for so long that I am wondering if anything happened to him.  I would have sent him Dr. E's new book if I knew. - 
  I'll see you in Moberly soon.

Affectionately,
Peggy Werkley
Completed

621 West Lee St.
Moberly, Mo.  65270
May 23, 1979
Dear Jack -

    I was so pleased to see the fine story about you in today's Paper.  I'm looking forward to the publication of underlined:  Jack Conroy Reader and hope the autobiography won't be put on the shelf, as you hinted, in today's story, that it might.  You have so many wonderful things to tell.
   One reason I have not dropped by to see  you & Gladys or called you again was the old Don't Push Into Someone Else's Busy Life belief.  I remember when I came back in the fall and called you, you were working frantically on your book
Completed

-2-
and other deadlines.   So I didn't want to bother the Sage of Moberly & have quietly settled down on West Lee street with the Hollow for company.

   Do give my best regards to Gladys & Penny, & keep a lot of my regards for yourself.

Peggy Werkley
(or Caroline E., as the confused Peggy sometimes calls herself)
Completed

in pencil in top margin Werkley, Peggy  [1980]
May 4, 1980
Dear Jack:

     I want to thank  you, for the Historical Society and Railroad Museum, as well as for myself personally, for lending your wonderful material for the 1980 Spring opening of the Museum.  I loved your Cornwall poem, even though you seemed to scan it (I'll be [sic] you really don't) because I've always been haunted by Cornwall & wanted so to go there.  I've read it's even warm
Completed

-2-
there, in  contrast to cold England in winter.  Weren't you underlined:  proud when those early works appeared?   I sometimes re-read my old poetry (only when I'm dumping from one carton to another) & say to myself - "That wasn't so bad."  Since I'm a unicorn-lover, I've a book of poetry opened, on a living room table, to William Rose Benét's "How To Catch Unicorns."  You know, of course, that the poor unicorn, in addition to liking virgins, liked hot-buttered batter-cake, "like foam to flake," and probably doesn't get them very often.
-3-

  I'll be bringing your material back home to you safely soon.
  Again, many thanks.

Sincerely,
Peggy Werkley
And my very, very best to Gladys. - & to Penny.
Completed

Christmas card  Dear Gladys & Jack   A very Merry Christmas And the best of wishes too...May the year ahead be wonderful In every way for you!  Peggy E. Werkley
in pencil in top margin  Werkley, Peggy  [1980]
Jack, I've got an enclosure for underlined:  you.  A friend in Maine was given it by a Pentecostal minister as my friend lay in the hospital following an operation.

   "Do you want to go to Heaven?"  the minister asked my friend.
  "No," growled Dabl. "I don't."

But he did receive this fascinating little booklet I'm sending you.   Now you know you didn't come from a monkey, you lucky man!  I reckon I did.

   I hope the autobiography is coming along well.  I think I'll try to write a mystery.  Peggy
Completed

greeting card  IMAGE;  two birds on an evergreen branch  CAREFREE CHICKADEES
-2-
that looking at trees has a healing effect.  If this is true, our far back ancestors who lived in forests would never have been sick!
Love - 
Peggy
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Werkley Peggy   Moberly, MO

Jan. 20, 1985
Jack dear -

   I can't get out to see you because of the weather, but I wanted you to know I was thinking of you & will be over to give  you one of my "healing treatments" as soon as I can.  I hope you are in a room that has a view of trees.  I have read (over)
Completed

postcard  postmark  OGLETHORPE UNIVERSITY GA  OCT 1 1945  10 30 AM

Don West
Oglethorpe University Ga.

Jack Conroy
Chicago Defender 
Chicago, Ill.
Completed

Dear Jack:

   Sent you an Autographed copy of my book underlined:  Clods of Southern Earth.  Hope you can review it.  You may know it.  Sold 13 thousand copies before coming from press.  ? the Institute of Applied Rel. Brisborn, Ala. ordered 8 thousand, and they say its going well all over. - Be glad to hear from you -

Cordially
Don West
Completed

Saturday A.M.
Dear Jack: -

   We received your letter this a.m. and the 10 copies which  you requested are in the mail bag.
    Sorry not to have written you this week but have been so busy being "Miss Glauber" in this area I've had little time for anything but the work of trundling books around "town and country."
    I have placed a total of 74 copies here, plus 3 review copies to the papers all of whom (I am confident) will give it a review.
    Famous-Barr is going to give it a full table display so I took a snap shot of Wallis to them to use for the set-up.
    Three Arts Book Shop at  5717 Delmar and a second shop which they own are going to give it a window display using Wallis' head which was done by Watkins.
    This is the ground I have covered this past week and all stores have taken from 2 to 15 copies as a starter.
Completed

Stix Baer Fuller
Famous Barr -- (display)
Scruggs
Hagedorn
Doubleday
Foster Book Shop
University Drive Book Shop
Book Nook
Pen and Palette
Three Arts Book Shop (display)

    at each of the above mentioned stores, the buyers were acquainted with the book and had received a few calls for it which made me feel somewhat elated to say the least.
   Glauber has written twice this week from Decker Press begging for copies - which were also sent off this a.m.
   The whole business has gained such momentum that a second printing is imperative.
   We have mailed copies to Webster both to Louisville & New York and will send one to the Sun-Times.
   I have talked with Mr. Rice at Famous-Barr and he wants to arrange
Completed

an autograph deal the first of the year.  I think it a good idea because they can really plug it then, and are being most cooperative and responsive about it now.

   As to your party arrangements we will leave the details up to you and will arrive at whatever weekend you choose.  However, let us know so that I may work out things here. 
   You've no idea how huge a success this book has become and I intend to plug it until everyone in the country has heard of Graphite from Elsinore.
    Thank you so much for coming down for the weekend.  I might add that everyone I talked to in the bookstores was familiar with  your name - and spoke highly of you.
    Give my regards to Gladys and Tommy.  I was so glad you brought him with you.  He is a fine boy and given time will achieve a name for himself.
    Keep in touch with us and we will also be sending reports to you from time to time.  Thank Win for selling a couple of copies.  Everyone counts.

Charlotte.
Completed

Hello Jack:

    What price glory?  Wallie's face is red but only because he is bursting with pride!  We don't expect him to admit such an achievement but we're all chuckling with glee at such "rare" publicity.
     Do hope you can make it to St. Louis soon.   Congratulations on your forthcoming book.  In the meantime don't freeze your balls.
     Regards to family.

Charlotte
Completed

Dear Jack

  As Wallie related - we are all plastered -
   I only want to add a line saying that I think you are one of the best and your visit was all too short.
   I liked one of the poems - "tenement Room"
   Let us get together
Completed

on some more "Only night muffles Those visual cries Of the dismal room"

  I so enjoyed your visit - come whenever you can and as often as is possible
  You're a underlined:  great person Conroy - and don't let anyone or anything change it.

Love
Charlotte
Completed

Dear Jack -
Just a note to let you know I'm working hard for "Elsie" here.
Charlotte.
Completed
much more to follow but don't want you to swallow too much of a swan at a time.
Completed

   It does my heart good to know you still think of people in my position.  You'll never know what your last letter did for me.  You are so kind and sweet.  Really I can't say enough to tell you what it means to one in my circumstances to get a sweet letter from a real gentleman.  Thanks

13 December 1949,
Castle of Elsinore
3528 A Franklin Ave.
St. Lous, Mo.
Dear Jack -

    I hope that by now you have placed and underlined: sold a few copies.  Presume that you received the ones we sent you.
    If you have the time and a copy of the book I would very much appreciate the following lead: -
    Mr. H. A. Belt
    ℅ Fred Harvey
    1701 Railway Exchange Bldg.,
    Chicago, Ill.

He is buyer for all the books placed in the Fred H. book shops around the country.  I talked to Mr. Landenbacher and Mr. Ryan here and they seemed enthusiastic but said that the buying of bound books was entirely up to the Chicago Office.

     I impressed  upon them, the fact that it was a slender volume, easy to carry on the train and of much more profit than pocket ? in so
Completed

-2
far as the book store was concerned.  He will be glad (Longenbacher that is ) to stock it here if we can get an O.K. from Mr. Belt.

     Would you have the time to see him this weekend and point out its possibilities?  I could mail him a copy but I feel that a personal review and interview from that vantage point would be of more importance.
     Think it over and let me know.  I've sold a few more copies and have a list of about 50 names - which means I will sell no less than 45.  A new edition is imperative because we haven't even furrowed the ground, as yet, and it is ripe for planting which is what I am doing at the moment.
  I want to get the ball rolling as quickly as possible because if the stores make a few sales now they will really plug it after the holiday season.
  I would also appreciate your talking to Les Kennedy and dropping
Completed

-3
him off a copy if you have it to spare.  I think if you talked with him it would help much more than being sent a copy from here.

   We have sent review copies to Harvey Webster and Wallie sent one to Cyril Connolly.  Perhaps with the Horizon out of circulation he may do something.
    Charles, who is my twin brother, called long distance and said that he would plug it.  He teaches at Miami U., Oxford, O. and is getting his M.A. (music - piano) there.  He goes to Cincinnati every Sat. for a music lesson in the afternoon and attends the Symphony in the evening.
    He knows a few people who would never miss $2.00 not only in Cincinnati but also Philad., Sacramento and N.Y. - and Indpls.
    I feel certain that he can get rid of 100 copies easily.  He's as enthusiastic as I am, so you see what us Swede-Irish can do!
Completed

-4

   I would never plug Wallie's book without the confidence that I feel.  He is going places and I want to get him off to a good start by having a successful run on this book -- otherwise he might give up completely.
    Enough sentiment - I think you know how much I love him.  He [[underlined:  will] ] continue writing!
    I think I neglected to apologize in my last letter the fact that I was asleep and failed to bid you adieu.   It was unpardonable of me, according to Emily, but that let down and lack of sleep did me in.
   Your presence was more than welcome and you proved no hindrance as you seemed obliged to mention.
   I'm returning a key which was dropped and owe you .08c. which I found and feel sure is yours.
   Give my love to Tommy and best regards to Gladys.

Charlotte
in left margin  Tell Tommy to Write.
Completed

underlined:  Decker Press
15 December 1949
Dear Wallie:

    Tax has been away for almost 2 weeks now & I have been doing my best to keep things running.
     I have billed all the St. Louis book stores with whom Charlotte placed orders - but I must repeat again what I wrote before - cant you send me any copies???
    There are several orders just sitting on my desk for the book.  Conroy has written about his Chicago contacts and seems to be doing well.  Stu Brent (at the Seven Stores) has placed an order for 15 copies.  But I cant act on none of this unless I have books.
     How about it?  Can you send all that you can spare?
     When Tax comes back we can go into the matter of having more bound.  But I can't do that without him.  In the meantime, I need the books.

Sincerely, Robert  (Robert Glauber)
COPY
Completed

17 December 1949
Dear Lodge Member: -

      I am enclosing a copy of a letter received today from Decker Press.  Thought you might be interested altho I presume that he wrote you, also.  Wallie, with his usual generosity, sent him 10 more copies (or a total of 40).
      I have just talked with Mr. Schenk at Becktold Co. and they told me that they would like to have a two week period in which to bind another printing.  He said that usually they work on a three week schedule but could get it out in two.
     They are now binding another small book for him and Schenk told me that he had given them the usual rush act to get it out before Christmas.
     Sent off the review copies to Price and Kennedy.
     Thanks for placing your copies in such lucrative sounding establishments.  I'm looking forward to the January festival there.  
     Hope that you will have no need for digging a moat.  If  you should, I'll be glad to stack it with Miss. Channel cats,. etc.  I might even promote a statue
Completed

for you.  They certainly don't know what to do with the ones strung around this lazy ole southern town.

   By the way, the Doubleday Book Shop (downtown) was destroyed by fire which means we will get paid for the 10 copies I placed there.  Honestly though I had nothing to do with the thing!
  Keep us posted and we will do likewise.  In the meantime, have some fun for yourselves through the holiday season.

As ever,
Charlotte
Completed

19 December, 1949
Dear Jess and Shotsie -

    You may or may not have received our autograph party invitation since I addressed it to Virginia Ave.
     Sorry you missed the affair.  It was - as you know - for Wallie's book of poetry "Graphiti from Elsinore."
     Conroy, Tommy and a couple of his friends were down - Sullivan and entourage and many others attended the clambake which started at Little Bohemia and ended here.
    Conroy is planning
Completed

of you on Christmas day and hope that it will be a lovely one for you both.

    If you have time please stop by and say hello as we will be having open house on 25 December.
    Merry Christmas and a fairly sober New Year to two people whom I like and admire very much.

As ever,
Charlotte Wharton
in pencil  Wallie
Completed

a party in Chicago the second weekend of January.  Would like very much to have you two join in the hustle and bustle of a weekend up there.

    The book is going over very well.  We've sold nearly 300 copies and the thing is barely started.
    Thank you both for the Christmas card.  It was very thoughtful of you and much appreciated.
    We're not even trying to get cards out this year - due to the pressure of getting the book going.  We're sinking every cent into it but I feel that it is worthwhile.
    We will be thinking
Completed

to help ring the bells for what I hope will be a good new year.  More of that later.

   I'm so glad for Tommie.  Best of luck to him.  Hope he'll always be as happy as he is now......
   And always my love to you and Gladys et al.!
   Merry Christmas - I'll save my new Year greetings until I see you

As ever, Charlotte
I'll let Wallie blow his own trumpet for the nonce.  He's doing great.  More later.           
Save the mistletoe!
Completed

28 Jan., 1950.
Dear Conroys -

   I want to thank you for your hospitality - extended to a group of weary "Southerners." 
   I bow in appreciation of your belief in Will's book.  He has the ability and the shyness of a great writer -
Completed

I feel certain that he will really "go places" now, because he has gained a confidence which was completely lacking.
   We shall always remain indebted to you for making "Elsie" the success it deserved.
    The party was fabulous and very
Completed

well organized.

    I shall be forever greatful [sic] to  you for what you have done.

Sincerely,
Charlotte.
Completed

greeting card  Season's Greetings     Wallie
Dear Gladys,

  How are you, you old bag? - say hello to  your lovely daughter for me.   I am not greeting that old Bughouse Square sot, Jack Conroy, as he sent a letter to Biggs and Edith - and didn't send one to me.  I must be on the shit list.  If you don't get your annual Xmas letter from Pope Conroy, most valued of status symbols, it shows you are slipping   Wallie

in red ink under holiday greeting  Portrait of me, and Gaslight Square scene, by my daughter Minny.
